awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Connecting Across Distances: Remote Tactile Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will expand the methodologies and applications for computer-based haptics, by investigating how remote tactile communication, functioning in partnership with other contextual channels like speech, may facilitate supportive discourse for at-risk individuals. The research enhances infrastructure for research and education by building a testbed to study a heretofore unexplored mode of computer-assisted perception between people. It will advance science while promoting teaching, training, and learning by providing unique cross-disciplinary educational and learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Potentially, this new technology will facilitate greater partnership and emotional interaction among people, over long distances. This will help people understand the meaning of the other person's communications, maintain valued relationships, and enhance each other's well-being. It could usher in a new dimension in telecommunications that has significant economic potential.

A hardware and software testbed will be developed to study this sub-space of human-computer interaction, including tactile modalities and parameters (e.g., compression, pattern, and onset dynamics) and the timing between a tactile stimulus and the accompanying contextualizing channel. Input and output devices will be developed through iterative design, and evaluated by means of: (1) usability and characterization studies; (2) in-laboratory affective communication studies including a one-way controlled study to assess affect conveyance and a dyadic communication study for the range of communication dynamics supported;  (3) in vivo extended communication studies.  One connection to general communication theory is the hypothesis that tactile interaction conveys affect immediately without interposing any explicitly coded symbolic message.  More generally, this research will take an interdisciplinary approach that draws from and contributes to each participating discipline.  Broad dissemination will enhance scientific and technological understanding through publication of results and insights in the journals and conferences of the various fields represented in the project. All software developed will be shared in open source form.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID 19 pandemic highlighted the need for innovation in communication technology. The social distancing and isolation imposed by our response to the virus has exposed a shortcoming of our current communication technologies based on video, audio and text. Human touch is essential to our social and emotional wellbeing. Our research shows that remote touch technology has the potential to support interpersonal connections that only human touch can furnish beyond the transmission of voice and video.

To explore the impact of social remote touch, we developed an interactive touch technology that is able to deliver an upper-arm touch between people in real time. The system features force-feedback technology to give the users more intuitive control of the touch communication. We tested our remote touch technology in three communicative settings: (1) Music experience where the listener received timed touches in conjunction with music; (2) Synchronous dyadic discourse where both parties could originate and receive touch during an elicited video-teleconference conversation; and (3) Asynchronous dyadic discourse where the recipient experiences a recorded package of a personal audio or video message from a loved one alongside a stream of mediated touches.

In (1) we found that touch intensified the affective impact of music experiences, but only if the recipient believes that touch originated from someone familiar. Conversely, unfamiliar touch demonstrates an opposite effect. Our findings suggest that touch is an effective form of affective communication when given the right context and can be used to impact a “touch-media” recipient's affective experience. 

In (2) we found that the dyads spontaneously appropriated the touch interaction for affect conveyance that can be measured physiologically. Specifically, touch tends to accompany utterances with negative sentiments, and that these touches tend to create a soothing effect. Surprisingly, in (2), we found that the conversants also spontaneously appropriated the technology for a range of communicative purposes (e.g., turn-taking signals) that are not typically associated with real interpersonal touch. 

Findings from (1) and (2) revealed that it is difficult to interpret the exact meaning of each touch. However, the overall affective experience is maintained. While text assigns a certain emotion (e.g., ‘I love you’), (1) and (2) suggest that one does not necessarily have to assign a specific meaning to each touch in order to convey affect.

In (3) we found that users preferred to experience the recorded messages with mediated touch rather than no touch, and video messages with touch ranked the highest overall. 

Findings from (2) and (3) suggest that mediated touch can potentially become part of a new form of media. 

Taken together, our findings show that like natural human touch, our technology allows powerful affective communication within context – the relationship between the people communicating, the meaning of the accompanying communication channel, and the accompanying communication medium. We also show that like audio and video, touch can play a role in new multimedia. This multimedia can be recorded and experienced asynchronously, or it can serve as a real-time communication channel that adds emotional and socially-relevant impact. This can open the door to new exciting commercializable technologies grounded in the evidence provided by our research..

Our outcomes demonstrated the promise of remote touch to impact affective experience and  suggest important commercial applications for remote social touch technology.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Francis Quek
